story.title: Beneath Your Mask - Episode 4
story.storyDescription: An anonymous admirer is texting Heather at a costume party‚Ä¶
story.creator: web-uploader

author.bio: Chris Marie Green writes hot contemporary romance (like ‚ÄúBedroomies‚Äù!) plus urban fantasy. She also loves devouring pop culture and avoiding international incidents while traveling.

story.prePaywallNotification: Aww, poor Heather! No one has ever been interested in what‚Äôs beneath her masks üíî Will Nightwing be different? Tap back into Hooked to find out.
story.postPaywallNotification: Go Heather! She‚Äôs totally making the moves on Connor üíÉ Tap back into Hooked to see if it works.

messages.text: A couple days later, Heather texts Jenna.
As if today at work wasn‚Äôt long and shitty enough, I now stand before the door of doom‚Ä¶
Tell your mom hi and that I miss her taco casserole.
If I survive whatever my batty mother has in store, I‚Äôll be sure to let her know.
Come on, she‚Äôs not that bad.
I know. It‚Äôs just that she changed after Dad died, and I don‚Äôt know what to do with her.
So she‚Äôs a little sassy and promiscuous now‚Ä¶
A little?
Do you know what it‚Äôs like for a daughter to be ‚Äúthe mother‚Äù in a relationship with her own MOTHER?
Oh, buck up and get tonight over with.
Bleh.
Bleh yourself. You‚Äôre just cranky because you could be happily orgasming right now‚Ä¶
IF you had followed up with Nightwing after the party like I told you to.
He didn‚Äôt care enough to contact ME either, so no big loss.
He‚Äôs another one and done.
You‚Äôre so full of crap.
I‚Äôve seen you walking around the office like a zombie‚Ä¶
Heather rolls her eyes, shoves her phone into her purse, and exhales.
She knocks on her mom‚Äôs door.
Mom opens up right away with a big smile, a flashy dress, and a bottle of beer.
She gives the beer to Heather while she walks in.
Hi.
Hi yourself. Drink up, because I have some news!
I figured you would.
Oh, don‚Äôt be such a sourpuss. We‚Äôre going to have company any minute.
Heather takes a long swig of beer.
And guess what?
Please tell me you bought a chastity belt.
No, but close. I‚Äôm dating one man exclusively! And you‚Äôre meeting him tonight!
Hardly shocked by Mom‚Äôs news, Heather chugs the beer and walks to the kitchen for another.
She pities whoever this poor man is because Mom will NEVER settle down‚Äî
Not after her heart was broken by Dad‚Äôs death.
I was really hoping for the chastity belt, Mom.
How many times do I have to tell you to call me Kathy, honey?
I‚Äôm young enough to look like I‚Äôm your big sister, anyway, so why ruin the illusion?
When Heather doesn‚Äôt answer, her mom continues chattering.
By the way, his three sons are also coming here for dinner.
Already? Usually it takes a little longer for me to meet the whole family.
Honey, this time it‚Äôs for real!
Anyway, the boys are all wonderful, trustworthy firefighters like their standup daddy‚Ä¶
But watch out for the youngest one.
He‚Äôs probably a couple years older than you ‚Äî he‚Äôs at least twenty-five‚Ä¶
But he‚Äôs got LOTS of experience, if you know what I mean.
And what I MEAN is that he‚Äôs an arrogant slut who sleeps with anything.
Sounds lovely, Kathy.
As Heather starts on her second beer, her Mom‚Äôs boyfriend arrives with his family.
And, holy crap‚Ä¶
When Heather is introduced to the youngest son, Connor the Slut, she‚Äôs smitten.
His eyes are blue, his hair is black under the baseball cap he wears backward, and his stubble is carefree and sexy.
His smile is as lethal as a supervillain‚Äôs.
While everyone gets acquainted, Heather finds herself getting another beer with him in the kitchen‚Ä¶
He rolls his eyes, deadpanning an introduction.
So I‚Äôm guessing that you‚Äôre as excited about this meeting as I am?
You mean our parents dating? Wrong ‚Äî I‚Äôm SO over the moon about it.
Sarcasm alert. Believe me, I‚Äôm on the same frequency.
So is your dad a serial dater like my mom is?
He‚Äôs working on it. It‚Äôs been a while since Mom passed away, but he just started dating a month ago.
Oh, boy.
A guppy in the dating pond and the first thing he runs into is a barracuda.
Connor laughs in surprise, as if he‚Ä¶?
Nah. He can‚Äôt be appreciating her candor THAT much.
I should add that I love my mom very much.
But, just so you know, we‚Äôve had many men over for dinner before.
God, just look at my dad. He‚Äôs glowing around her.
I guess he is‚Ä¶
Unfortunately, she ends up breaking a lot of hearts. I hope your dad‚Äôs isn‚Äôt one of them.
Connor gives her another surprised yet interested look.
Wow, it‚Äôs suddenly real warm in this kitchen‚Ä¶
Listen, I‚Äôm only being honest with you because your dad seems like a nice guy.
Besides, it was a long day at work and I‚Äôm a bit drunk.
What do you do for work?
I hold the scintillating position of personal assistant to a CEO.
You don‚Äôt like what you do?
Let‚Äôs just say I plan to get more out of life.
Frowning, she switches the topic. Somehow, she‚Äôs enjoying her conversation with the slut.
So my mom told me you‚Äôre a firefighter.
Pardon me while I feel relatively useless compared to THAT.
He raises his eyebrows and she winces.
Sorry. But I told you ‚Äî I‚Äôm extra blunt tonight.
Blunt is refreshing.
It is?
To be honest, women aren‚Äôt usually themselves around me.
Oh. Do they try too hard to impress you?
I can‚Äôt imagine why that would be.
She gestures with her bottle toward the muscles under his tee and‚Ä¶
Well, the whole damned lust-inducing package, really.
Connor chuckles.
I guess firefighters do have a built-in appeal for some women.
But sometimes they just see the firefighter uniform and don‚Äôt look beyond that.
Your attempt at humility is endearing.
I hear that sarcasm alert going off again.
Come on, let‚Äôs not fool each other. You can‚Äôt possibly be humble.
Firemen have groupies. Everyone knows that.
Truthfully, getting laid a lot was kind of a perk when I first started the job.
But then I realized that I actually love what I do, and that‚Äôs what should matter.
Ah, a true-blue hero right here in my mom‚Äôs kitchen.
As he goes quiet, he sends her a long look, as if he‚Äôs trying to see past her bravado.
Electric desire zings through Heather, and she tamps it down.
Just so you know, I‚ÄôM not a groupie.
And giving me that kind of slut-boy look isn‚Äôt going to make me one.
You sure like to talk enough about groupies.
It‚Äôs a fascinating subject.
One we could chat about for hours, I‚Äôm sure.
He grins wickedly, obviously teasing her.
You know, I was thinking about bowing out of this dinner to go somewhere else.
Interested?
You want to get out of here. With me.
Why not?
Because I‚Äôm not remotely your type.
You mean a groupie?
Yeah, a groupie with every straight hair in place.
He gives her a cocky, playful grin.
In spite of herself, she bites back a smile, thinking about Nightwing and how cocky HE was.
You‚Äôre smiling.
No, I‚Äôm not.
A smile like that is a sure sign that you‚Äôre thinking about leaving here with me.
Did you have something else planned for tonight?
I could if I wanted to.
Heather nearly shivers as she thinks about texting Nightwing.
Maybe she should do it and scratch this itch that Connor has given her‚Ä¶
She starts to leave, looking over her shoulder at him.
Where‚Äôre you going?
Somewhere ‚Äî anywhere to get away from the hero in this kitchen.
I‚Äôve been saving people all day, but I‚Äôve been saving MYSELF for a superhero.
Connor‚Äôs expression changes ever so slightly just before Heather leaves him behind.
A couple hours later, after dinner, Heather takes a shared ride to the subway.
She‚Äôs flustered because of Connor, who kept sneaking curious looks at her throughout the meal.
Maybe he was just miffed that she turned him down?
As she wrestles with thoughts of him, her phone dings with a text.
She smiles at the new name she‚Äôs given her Ballsy Admirer.
I‚Äôve been wondering, Cap‚Ä¶
What other costumes do you like to wear?
